div1.p: Legation of Belgium in Washington No 830/369 Congo and the protestant missions

I received last spring the visit from Mr. Joseph Clark, baptist missionary, who has lived in the Congo for around twenty years, and who is particularly distinguished in the violent country lead by the protestant missions of the United States against the old Independent State of the Congo. He was accompanied by another member of the mission Mr. Richards. We had a long conversation, and I spared them an interview in Brussels with Mr. Minister of the Colonies at the moment of their depart from the Congo.

These gentlemen returned to see me today, sent from Boston, for the "American Baptist Foreign Mission Society Commission to the Congo Mission and the Sudan.", to thank me for the welcome that I made to them a few months ago, they told me what followed.
We have just made a long voyage in the interior of the Belgian Congo, We were at 100 milles beyond
His Excellence Mister Davignon, in Brussels
Coquilhoutville and penetrated the heart of the regions of exploitation of the rubber.
We care to tell you that there where we were other times with reclamations false a single indigenous during our whole voyage did not address themself to us to complaoin of whatever this is.
We will send to you under little a letter on the part of the "American Foreign Mission Society" with which you can make such use that pleases you.

I would like to add Mr. Joseph Clarke to express the particular esteem that we inspired a belgian officer commanding the district of Coquilhatrille who was named Duborcq I believe. He has a brother who is also an officer: this information could aid the indiginous the person of which is question gives the case of error in the orthography of his name.
I have the honor l signed Couras de Buisseret
